She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and her children’s studies. A dream for most poor Filipino parents, like Ligaya, as she herself has been an undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Ma. Ligaya operates a fruit stand. She buys seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the south region of Luzon. She also sells bananas, papayas and other Filipino fruit staples. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 600  every day.

To help her continued business operations, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fruit to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ma. Ligaya dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for fruit deliveries for her business.

loans.name: Manala

texts.en: At present, she is working in another saloon. she want to rent a shop and make a saloon.

loans.use: to rent a shop and make a saloon.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 42 year-old business lady, she is married to Musili who is her spouse. They are blessed with three children ages 16, 14 and 8 years old respectively. She has been running a retail shop for the past five years with a monthly income of KES 5,000 which she uses to support the family needs.

She is applying for her first loan from Kiva partner KADET after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Mary will use the loan to add a stock of rice, sugar and wheat flour. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, she will educate her children and expand the business. Her hopes and dreams are to buy commercial land and build rental houses.

loans.use: to add stock of rice, sugar and wheat flour.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy chickens and red meat.

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Sary is 46 years-old and her husband, Veasna, is 43 years-old.  They live in a village along National Road number five approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1990 and have a son who is a woodcarver. 

Sary and her husband are fishers and farmers. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new boat and motor for her fishing business.   

Photo: Sary and her husband.

loans.use: to purchase a new boat and motor for her fishing business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: She will use the loan for her business expansion, paying the school fees of her children and building a new house. she have 4 children 2 are schooling and she is marriage

loans.use: Grandnut,maze buy & Sale.

loans.name: Kimsruon

texts.en:
Kimsruon, 38, sells Cambodian cake and dessert in her village. Her husband Sokhrong, 39, is a construction worker. He also is hired by his fellow villagers to farm and get fees. Kimsruon and her husband live along National Road Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1995 and have three sons and two daughters. 

Kimsruon is asking for her first loan of $500 to add to her own money to build a new house in which to stay. 

Photo: Kimsruon and her husband.

loans.use: to add to her own money to build a new house in which to stay

loans.name: Malingi

texts.en:
Malingi is a 33-year-old married father of three children who are between nine and three years old. Malingi is a tailor in Kilifi. His business has been in operation for the last three years and has been a success. 

Malingi has been a KADET client and this marks his second borrowing to finance his business. With this loan he plans to purchase cloth materials, threads, needles, buttons and zippers for his business. 

The anticipated profits will be used to repay back the loan and to gradually expand his business. His dream is to prosper in life.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials, threads, needles, buttons and zippers

loans.name: Tsuma

texts.en:
Tsuma is 34 years old, married, and a father of four children who are between two and twelve years old. Tsuma is a draftsman in Mariakani. His business has been in operation for the last eight years and has been a success. 

Tsuma has been a KADET client and this marks his second borrowing to finance his business. With this loan he plans to purchase drawing materials to enable him to draw plans, sections and profiles for his business. 

The anticipated profits will be used to repay the loan, to gradually expand his business, and to start up a tailoring business. His dream is to own a construction company.

loans.use: to purchase drawing materials to enable him to draw plans, sections and profiles

loans.name: Sreymao

texts.en:
Sreymao (pictured here) runs a grocery store at home. Her husband, Chan, is a construction worker. She is applying for a loan of $600 to purchase additional grocery items for her inventory.

The couple lives on an island located 15 kilometers Phnom Penh City. They have two sons and three daughters.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her inventory.

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is 40 years old, married, and has five children. She has been farming for two years. She was previously tailoring to earn a living. She has grown her business through Faulu Kenya, hence improving her standard of living. 

In five years, she hopes to grow the business for more income generation. She has requested 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy seedlings.

loans.use: To buy seedlings

loans.name: Chekmach

texts.en:
Chekmach is a farmer and lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She is a widow with three daughters. Two have full-time employment and another one stays at home. 

Chekmach is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her daughters to drive to work.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary has a small food stall. After receiving this money, she will expand her business so that she can send her children to school.

loans.use: to expand her food business.

loans.name: Sokhan

texts.en:
Sokhan (in the photo), 41, is a widowed mother with two sons and one daughter. All of them are in school. The family lives in a village along National Road number five, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokhan sells fish. She buys fish from Prek Phnao market and carries them by bicycle to sell them in her village. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to build a restroom and to fill up the land under her house.

loans.use: to build a restroom and to fill up the land under her house.

loans.name: Koemleang

texts.en:
Koemleang (in the photo) is 37 years old and his wife, Sokken, is 33 years old. They live along National Road Six about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1998 and have two children - one son and one daughter.

Koemleang is a driver. He drives for a company. His wife is a farmer. He is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.name: Sokros

texts.en:
Sokros (pictured here,) 27, is a construction worker. His wife, Naret, 25, is a weaver. They have been married since 2008 and just have a young son. They live on an island located 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokros is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting. Because he does not have his own motorbike, he commutes to work with his villagers very often. He will use a part of the loan to repair part of his house.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for commuting and to repair part of his house.

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen is married with two children. Sheis 32 years old and lives in Plaridel.

Karen sells jewelry to earn a living and has had this business for six years. Each month, she earns PHP 1000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for PHP 20,000 to purchase jewelry to sell.

Karen has been a member of PMPC for seven years.

loans.use: to purchase jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Adeth's Group

texts.en:
Adeth is a widow who has two sons. Both of them are young and do work to survive financially. The eldest one grows different fruits by renting a garden and the youngest one works in a food restaurant. She stays at home to do her household responsibilities. Adeth has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest son who will use the loan to pay rent in advance for his garden so he will be able to grow fruit without any problem and generate the maximum profits. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Adeth is hopeful that an investment will put her son’s business in a more profitable position and improve the living standard of her family. 
 
Both of her sons are unmarried and she is hopeful that she will be able to save some profits for the marriage of her eldest son in the near future. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 
 
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Adeth.

loans.use: To pay the rent for a garden to grow fruit

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is a 21-year-old single man. To earn a living, he runs a salon and a cosmetics shop. Besides that, he also does carpentry for more income generation. He has managed to grow his business through Faulu Kenya because he has been trained in business management skills.  

Alex dreams of owning rental houses in the future. He has requested 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy chairs for the salon and a shaving machine.

loans.use: To buy chairs for the salon and a shaving machine.

loans.name: Feleciana

texts.en: Feleciana is married with no children. Feleciana is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. Feleciana is a farmer and raises pigs to earn a living. She has been doing this for three years. She has requested a loan for 10,000 PHP to purchase more pigs to sell. Feleciana has been a member of PMPC for five years.

loans.use: to purchase more pigs

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel is 32 years old and married with three children between the ages of three and six years old. She has been operating a well-organized business for one year selling clothes including clothing for the elderly and for children. She opens her business from 6am until 6pm daily except on Sunday. 

Rachel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase more clothes to sell such as elder's clothes and children's clothes. With this profit, Rachel will reinvest in her business and save for her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is 30. She is married and has four children. After taking this loan, she will expand her business and her income will increase, then she can easily bear her children educational expenses.

loans.use: for expanding her business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 37 years old and lives in Plaridel. She is married with three children. 

Lucy has a bamboo furniture business and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 20,000 PHP to purchase materials for her bamboo furniture. 

Lucy has been a member of PMPC for three years.

loans.use: to purchase materials for bamboo furniture.

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman is a young woman from Jabalia Refugee camp in Gaza Strip. She is married to a barber. Iman's husband started his shop three years ago and has established a good number of customers.

Iman came to FATEN and took out a $1,000 loan to help her husband improve the shop. Iman's husband needed a new barber kit and hair creams. He also wanted to use the entire space in the shop but he couldn't cover the expenses from the shop's income. Therefore, she took out the loan.

Iman is a religious woman, as are most of Gaza Strip inhabitants. Therefore, her husband is shown in the picture here.

loans.use: to purchase a barber kit and creams

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is 55 years old and lives in Lopez Jaena. She is married with three children. 

Julieta has a general store business, and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 50,000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store. 

Julieta has been a member of PMPC for 11 years.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is 41 years old, married and has four children. Her two eldest sons are daily wage laborers, her youngest son is illiterate and her daughter is studying in class 9th. Her husband is a mason and provides construction services to different construction companies and people looking to build homes. He is the only breadwinner in the family. 

Razia is a caring lady, carrying out her responsibilities of a housewife very well. She cooks food for her family and keeps her house clean. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband who wants to buy masonry tools that will allow him to provide better quality services to his customers and increase his profits. He has been operating this business for the past 15 years and Razia is hopeful that after the loan investment, he will be able to improve his income further. 

Razia is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Razia.

loans.use: To buy masonry tools

loans.name: Jeanne D'arc

texts.en:
Jeanne D'arc is 27 years old. She is married with one child who is 1 year old. Jeanne D'arc owns a small business selling various styles of African clothes for women. This business is well-known and organized. The hours of her business are from 7 a.m. until 6 p.m. every day except on the weekend. She has one year of experience in this business.

Jeanne D'arc has requested her first loan from Kiva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, in order to expand her business by purchasing more African clothes for women for sale. Once this expansion is reached, Jeanne D'arc will be able to earn more profit. She wants her business to be wholesale. With any profits, she will build her own house and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more African clothes for sale.

loans.name: Cherielyn

texts.en: Cherielyn is 41 years old and lives in Plaridel. She is married with four children. Cherielyn works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for 10 years. She has requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to purchase more fish to sell. Cherielyn has been a member of PMPC for 10 years.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Siham

texts.en: Siham, who is photographed with her husband in the picture here in FATEN's branch in Hebron, is a 48-year-old mother of five daughters and four sons. Two of her sons are construction workers and the rest are young school students. Siham and her husband run a goat farm in the village of Bani Nuiem in Hebron. They raise and sell goats, Siham came to FATEN to take a $900 loan to purchase more goats and increase their dairy products, which will increase the farm's sales and improve the family's income. Bani Nuiem is famous for raising cattle and dairy products.

loans.use: to buy more goats

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: She is 28 years old and married with four children.  Three of her children are now in school. If she can open a beauty salon, she can send another child to school.

loans.use: To open a beauty salon

loans.name: Willy

texts.en:
Willy is 28 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is single and has no children.  

Willy has a business of a health clinic, which he has had for less than one year. He also has a second business of a piggery. 

To help expand his health clinic business, Willy has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase medicine for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Willy hopes to generate greater profits and take care of himself like buying new clothes.  

In the future, Willy hopes to expand his business by increasing his stock.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for resale.

loans.name: Edhmie

texts.en: Edhmie is married with one child. Edhmie is 24 years old and lives in Plaridel. Edhmie sells a variety of products in her general store to earn a living and has had this business for five years. Each month, she earns PHP 2,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 20,000 to purchase more stock for her general store. Edhmie has been a member of PMPC for five years.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
She is 29 Age.  She has 5 Children.  3 are in school.

her husband is a church leader .  She wants to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is 26 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is single and has no children. Henry has a business of a boutique that sells clothes, which he has had for less than one year.         

To help expand his business, Henry has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Henry hopes to generate greater profits and take care of himself like buying new clothes.  

In the future, Henry hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel is married with 4 children.  Manuel is 57 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Manuel is a farmer and grows pigs to earn a living.  He has been doing this for 3 years.  He has requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to purchase more pigs to raise and sell.  Manuel has been a member of PMPC for 3 years.

loans.use: to purchase more pigs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase food such as bananas, maize flour, rice, cassava,etc fo use at the hotel

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen is 46 years old, married and has four sons. Due to financial constraints, Perveen could not provide education for her children. Her eldest son has a construction supplies business, two are daily wage laborers while the youngest son is 17 years old and stays at home.
Perveen's husband has an animal sales business. He buys young animals, raises them up and then sells them to butchers for a profit. His sales increase around Eid (a Muslim festival) because people slaughter animals. At other times he sells them to butchers.
Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to help her husband in his business. With the loan, he will buy goats and sheep for resale. He started this business 15 years ago and it is doing well. Perveen hopes that her husband's business will make even more income after the loan investment. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she established good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.
Note: In the photo, the lady with the book (an Asasah Passbook) is Perveen.

loans.use: to buy goats and sheep for resale.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is 43 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is widowed and has four children. Two of her children are currently in school.  

Prossy has a business of selling timber that is used for building houses. She has had this business for less than one year. She also has a second business of rental houses.  

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase timber for building houses. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  

In the future, Prossy hopes to expand her business into a bigger one.

loans.use: to purchase timber.

loans.name: Djiguisseme I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe DJIGUISSEME I sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Fala, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, FATOUMATA qui est la première debout à droite, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour, de sarclage pour entretenir environs 1 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60 000FCFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group DJIGUISSEME I are married women who average 36 years of age and three children living in polygamous families in Fala, a village in the Commune of Massigui, Prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of organizing their businesses better at the start of the off-season. The crops grown include rice and peanuts. The group members are on their fifth collaboration with the institution. 

With this new loan, FATOUMATA, who is the first one standing at the right (in the photo), intends to buy farm inputs and sundry supplies and equipment and to pay for plowing and weeding for maintaining about one hectare of rice and peanuts.

After the harvests, the produce is sold in the city of Massigui to a customer base composed of women and men. The women plan on making an average profit of about 60,000 francs CFA for each planting season.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seeds, manure, weeding, and sundry supplies and equipment

loans.name: Gbenonkpo 3 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe GBENONKPO 3 est composé de trois personnes qui habitent la même maison. C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe du nom de Charlotte est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Charlotte a 47 ans et vit au Bénin.  Charlotte est mariée à un certain Basile. Le couple à six enfants tous scolarisés, et encore à leur charge. Les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Charlotte mène comme activité depuis quinze ans la vente de friperie. A côté de cette activité qui lui procure de revenus, Charlotte vend du pain, de l'huile d'arachide et de palme. Charlotte s’approvisionne dans l’un des  marchés du  Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires  et son revenu, Charlotte sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBENONKPO 3, un second crédit.
texts.en: The GBENONKPO 3 group is composed of three people who live in the same house.  This is the second time that this group has asked for financial aid from ALIDé, in order to increase their business.  Charlotte, the group’s representative, is the one with her hand raised in the photo.  She is 47 years old and lives in Bénin.  Charlotte is married to Basile.  The couple has six dependent children who are all in school.  The children live with their parents.  To provide for her needs and those of her children, Charlotte has operated a business selling second hand clothes for fifteen years.  In addition to this business that provides income for her, Charlotte sells bread, peanut oil and palm oil.  Charlotte gets her supplies in one of Bénin’s markets.  Charlotte, together with the other members of the GBENONKPO 3 group, is requesting a second loan with the goal of satisfying her customers and increasing her sales and income.

loans.use: To buy bread, peanut oil and palm oil

loans.name: Djiguisseme Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les six  membres du groupe DJIGUISSEME II sont des femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à Fala, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, KARATOU, assise au milieu, compte acheter les intrants et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 0,5 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25.000FCFA environs  en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The six members of the group DJIGUISSEME II are married women who average 35 years of age and three children living in polygamous families in Fala, a village in the Commune of Massigui, Prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of organizing their businesses better at the start of the off-season. The crops grown include rice and peanuts. The group members are on their fifth collaboration with the institution. 

With this new loan, KARATOU, who is seated in the middle (in the photo), intends to buy farm inputs and to cover the cost of plowing for maintaining about 0.5 hectares of rice and peanuts.

After the harvests, the produce is sold in the city of Massigui to a customer base composed of women and men. KARATOU plans on making an average profit of about 25,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seeds, and manure

loans.name: Prince 1 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe PRINCE 1 est composé de trois personnes qui habitent la même localité. C'est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe du nom de Gisèle est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Gisèle a 46 ans et vit au Bénin. Gisèle est mariée à un menuisier du nom de Joseph. Le couple à trois enfants tous scolarisés, et ne vivant plus avec eux. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de son mari, Gisèle mène comme activité depuis trente ans la vente du maïs et de la farine de manioc. A côté de cette activité Gisèle vend des produits divers. Gisèle s’approvisionne dans l’un des plus grands marchés du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Gisèle sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe PRINCE 1, un premier crédit.
texts.en: The PRINCE 1 group is composed of three people who live in the same area.  This is the first time that this group has asked for financial aid from ALIDé, so as to grow their businesses.  Gisèle, the group’s representative, is the one with her hand raised in the photo.  Gisèle is 46 years old and lives in Benin.  She is married to Joseph, a carpenter.  The couple has three children who have all been to school and no longer live with them.  To provide for her needs and those of her husband, Gisèle has operated a business selling corn and manioc flour for thirty years.  In addition to this business, Gisèle sells various products.  Gisèle gets her supplies in one of Benin’s largest markets.   Gisèle is asking for a first loan, together with the other members of the PRINCE 1 group, with the goals of satisfying her customers and expanding her sales and income.

loans.use: To buy bags of corn and manioc flour.

loans.name: Djiguisseme Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les six  membres du groupe DJIGUISSEME III sont  des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et  en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Fala, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont le mil, le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SÉTOU, assise au milieu, compte acheter les intrants et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare  riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA environs en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The six members of the Djiguisseme III group are married women who average 32 years of age and have an average of three children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Fala, one of the villages in the municipality of Massigui, in the prefecture of Dioïla, which lies in Koulikoro, Mali's second administrative region.

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They grow millet, rice and groundnut. They are on their sixth loan from the institution. 

With this new loan, Sétou, who is sitting in the middle, is planning to buy farm inputs and pay labor costs necessary to maintain around one hectar of rice and groundnut. 

The produce is sold once harvested in the town of Massigui to a customer base made up of men and women. She is planning to make an average profit of around 40,000FCFA at the end of the season.

loans.use: to pay for labor, seeds, fertilizer and weedkiller

loans.name: Sedjro-Kpon Group

texts.fr: SEDJRO-KPON est un groupe constitué de trois personnes et dont la  présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Solange Félicité. Les membres du groupe appartiennent à la même famille et vivent dans le même quartier. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupe sollicite pour la troisième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Solange Félicité a 45 ans et vit au Bénin. Solange Félicité est mariée à un magasinier du nom de Magloire. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés et ne vivant plus avec eux. Après avoir arrêté l’école au secondaire, Solange Félicité a commencé depuis près de six ans la vente des ustensiles de cuisine. A côté de cette activité, Solange Félicité vend de la friperie. Solange Félicité s'approvisionne dans l'un des marché du Bénin. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à ainsi assurer les diverses charges de la famille. Ce troisième prêt permettra certainement à Solange Félicité et aux autres membres du groupe SEDJRO-KPON, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
Sedjro-Kpon is a group composed of three people whose president (who is raising her hand in the picture) is named Solange Félicité. The group members belong to the same family and live in the same neighborhood. To increase their working capital, this group is requesting a loan from ALIDé for the third time.
Solange Félicité is 45 years old and lives in Benin. Solange Félicité is married to a shopkeeper named Magloire. The couple has four children, who all went to school, and no longer live with them. Having left school in middle school, Solange Félicité started selling kitchen utensils six years ago. In addition to this activity, Solange Félicité sells second-hand clothes. She procures her goods from one of Benin's markets. This activity generates revenues which help her contribute to the family's various expenses.
This third loan will definitely allow Solange Félicité and the other members of group Sedjro-Kpon to raise their level of activity and to grow their clientele and sales.

loans.use: to buy kitchen utensils and second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Tiessiri I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tièssiri I sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Baba, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, BAGNESSIRA, qui est la première debout à droite, compte acheter les intrants et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 0,5 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 20.000FCFA environs en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Tièssiri I group are married women with an average age of 39, and an average of 3 children each. Most of them live in polygamous families in Baba, one of the villages in the  commune of Massigi, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro prefecture, 2nd administrative district of Mali. They are working with micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They grown rice, groundnuts, and other crops.

This is their 5th loan with Soro Yiriwaso. With the new loan, Bagnessira, 1st person standing on the right, plans to buy farm inputs and pay for plowing costs for 0.5 hectares of rice and groundnuts. The crops are sold in Massigui after the harvest, to customers who are both men and women. Bagnessira expects to make an average profit of around 20,000 CFA francs at the end of the season.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seed, fertilizer and weedkiller.

loans.name: C1186 Ituze Group

texts.en:
Ladislas is 46 years old and is married with seven children between the ages of 5 and 23 years old.  He is the president of a group called “Ituze”. Ladislas is the first person in the left side. 

He sells products such as bananas, beans and sorghum.  Ladislas employs two people to help him and has been working for twelve years.  He operates his business from 7am to 8pm everyday.

Ladislas and his group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more products such as bananas, beans and sorghum for sale. With the profits from the loan, Ladislas and his team would like to satisfy the basic needs of their families, reinvest in their businesses and start saving.

loans.use: To buy more products such as bananas, beans and sorghum for sale.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en: She is married.  Age is 35.  Her husband is an army person.  She has 6 children.  3 are in school.  Income is very low.  If she can expand her business then her income will increase.

loans.use: Fruit and vegetable business

loans.name: Mupa

texts.en:
Mupa is a widow with six children, four of whom attend school while two are still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, Mupa has operated a grocery selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a retail shop business which contributes as her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. Mupa dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fruits, sugar, wheat flour and maize flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fruits, sugar, wheat flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Tiessiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tièssiri 1 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et  en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kenikela, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, GNASSA GAOUSSSOU, qui la première debout à gauche compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour (sarclage) pour entretenir environs 1 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50 000FCFA environs par campagne
texts.en:
The ten members of the Tièssiri 1 group are married women who average 42 years of age and have an average of two children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Kenikela, one of the villages in the municipality of Massigui, in the prefecture of Dioïla, which lies in Koulikoro, Mali's second administrative region.

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They grow among other things rice and groundnut. They are on their fifth loan with the institution.

With this new loan, Gnassa Gaousssou, who is standing on the far right, is planning to buy farm inputs, small tools and to pay for labor costs (hoeing) to maintain around one hectar of rice and groudnut.

The produce is sold once harvested in the town of Massigui to a customer base made up of men and women. They are expecting to make an average profit of around 50,000FCFA per season.

loans.use: to pay for labor, seeds, fertilizer, weedkiller, hoeing and small tools

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is the high cost of transportation in the business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of sugar, wheat flour and bundles of clothes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar, wheat flour and bundles of clothes.

loans.name: Tiessiri Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tièssiri II sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Baba, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AMINATA MOUSSA, qui est debout au milieu, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labours pour entretenir environs 0,8  hectares de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 80.000FCFA environs en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of group Tièssiri II are married women who are on average 43 years old with three children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Baba, one of the villages of Massigui Township is Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (Mali's second administrative region).
They are partnering with micro-finance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their activities at the start of the rainy season. They cultivate rice and groundnuts among other crops. They are on their fifth collaboration with the organization.
With this new loan, Aminata Moussa - who is standing in the middle in the picture - plans on buying agricultural inputs and small equipement. She will also pay for plowing costs to maintain about 1.9 acres of rice and groundnuts.
After the harvest, productions are sold in the town of Massigui to a clientele comprising men and women. Aminata expects an average profit of about 80,000 CFA at the end of the agricultural cycle.

loans.use: to pay for plowing costs, seeds, fertilizer and small equipment.

loans.name: Kadide

texts.en:
Kadide is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a poultry business, selling as wholesale to her neighbours and passersby. She faces major challenges of poultry disease outbreak and the high cost of transportation. Kadide dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase chicks and chicken feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Tiessiri 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tièssiri 2 sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans et ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kenikela, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, KARIA, assise au milieu,  compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour (sarclage)pour entretenir environs 1 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75.000FCFA environs  en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Tièssiri 2 group are married women who average 29 years of age and have an average of two children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Kenikela, one of the villages in the municipality of Massigui, in the prefecture of Dioïla, which lies in Koulikoro, Mali's second administrative region.

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They grow among other things rice and groundnut. They are on their fifth loan with the institution.

With this new loan, Karia, who is sitting in the middle, is planning to buy farm inputs, small tools and to pay for labor costs (hoeing) to maintain around one hectar of rice and groundnut.

The produce is sold once harvested in the town of Massigui to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average profit of around 75,000FCFA at the end of the season.

loans.use: to pay for labor, seeds, fertilizer, hoeing and small tools

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira, 43, is the leader of this group. She is married and has three children, the youngest of whom is 15. Damira is an accountant and her husband is a security officer in the same company. The monthly income for the family is 6,000 soms. Damira’s husband is looking forward to starting to drive a cab in his free time from work. In order to do this, he has found a suitable automobile in good condition; however, the price isn’t affordable for the family. 

Damira was in despair, until her oldest son, who is employed in the banking sector, suggested that she learn about the project Kiva. With much excitement, Damira learnt about all the conditions of the loan and applied for the loan through Kiva’s field partner in Kyrgyzstan, Mol Bulak Finance. Damira has high hopes of financial assistance from lenders, because it would help her in a big way in the purchase of an automobile. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a car to use as a taxi

loans.name: Omurbek's Group

texts.en:
Omurbek, 36, is a member of this group. He is a resident of a small fishing town, Balykchi. He is one of 42,000 residents with his own ideas of running a small business. “Being the main breadwinner of the family and having a one-year-old son motivates me to try new things, and help the family make a living”, says Omurbek. He is involved in two main activities: working in a local small joint-stock company and purchasing young cattle, fattening and reselling them. 

In December 2010, Omurbek applied for a loan of 15,000 soms from a local bank for the business start-up. After providing thorough care for a couple of months, he resold the animal for a good deal. This activity yielded a monthly income of 6,000 soms. Currently he owns two head of livestock, which he will also take care of and resell later. Having learnt about the loan opportunity from Kiva, Omurbek informed his like-minded fellows and gathered a group. The purpose of the loan is to purchase a calf for further growing and reselling. Omurbek hopes that someday in future he will build the house of his dreams for his family. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf for fattening and resale

loans.name: C9600 Kabare Ii Group

texts.en:
Dorothee is 41 years old, married and the mother of six children aged between 6 months and 18 years old. Dorothee is the leader of the group called "KABARE II". Her business is well-known, selling vegetables and has been in operation for 20 years, working from 6 a.m. until 1 p.m. every day except on Saturday. She currently employs five people to help her. In the photo, Dorothee is the second person from the right.

Dorothee and her team have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase their vegetable businesses by purchasing more good vegetables for sale. They will reinvest additional profits into their businesses and save money to pay their children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase more good vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Tiessiri Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Tièssiri III sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames à Baba, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt,  DJOKOURA qui est debout au milieu, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour (sarclage) pour entretenir environs 1 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75.000FCFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of group Tièssiri III are married women who are on average 33 years old with three children. They live in polygamous families in Baba, one of the villages of Massigui Township in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (Mali's second administrative region).
They are partnering with micro-finance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They cultivate rice and groundnuts among other crops. They are on their fifth collaboration with the organization.
With this new loan, Djokoura - who is standing in the middle - plans on buying agricultural inputs and small equipment, and to pay for weeding costs to maintain about 2.5 acres of rice and groundnuts.
After the harvest, the crops are sold in the town of Massigui to a clientele comprising men and women. She expects an average benefit of 75,000 CFA per agricultural cycle.

loans.use: to pay for plowing costs, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and small equipment.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati is a divorced woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her child.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a grocery selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenge of perishability in the vegetables for sale. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, sweet potatoes, green vegetables and cabbages. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, sweet potatoes, green vegetables and cabbages to sell.

loans.name: Baida

texts.en: G., is 45 year old she, has six children, four of them are in school. Her husband is also a businessman. She sells beer, sugar, rice, etc. She wants to expand her business and paying school fees

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Tiessiri 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Tiessiri 3 sont des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 37 ans, 2 enfants et qui vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kenikela, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, KARIDIATOU, qui est debout au milieu, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour (sarclage) pour entretenir environs 0,8 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50 000FCFA environs en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The six members of group Tiessiri 3 are married women who are on average 37 years old with two children; most of them live in polygamous families in Kenikela, one of the villages of Massigui Township in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (Mali's second administrative region).
They are partnering with micro-finance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They cultivate rice and groundnuts among other crops. They are on their fifth collaboration with the organization.
With this new loan, Karidiatou - who is standing in the middle - plans on buying agricultural inputs and small equipment, and to pay for weeding costs to maintain about 2 acres of rice and groundnuts.
After the harvest, the crops are sold in the town of Massigui to a clientele comprising men and women. They expect an average benefit of about 50,000 CFA at the end of the agricultural cycle.

loans.use: to pay for plowing costs, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and small equipment.

loans.name: Tiessiri Iv Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Tièssiri IV sont  des femmes mariées ayant en moyenne  29 ans, en moyenne 4 enfants et  vivant  dans des familles polygames à Baba, un des villages de la commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AWA  compte acheter les intrants et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 0,25 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de  Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 15.000FCFA environs  en  fin  de campagne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the group Tièssiri IV are married women who average 29 years of age and 4 children. They all live in polygamous families in Baba, a village in the Commune of Massigui, Prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of organizing their work better at the start of the off-season. The crops grown include rice and peanuts. The group members are on their fifth collaboration with the institution. 

With this new loan, AWA intends to buy farm inputs and to pay for plowing in order to maintain about 0.25 hectare of rice and peanuts.

After the harvests, the produce is sold in the city of Massigui to a customer base composed of women and men. AWA plans on making an average profit of about 15,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seeds, and manure

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a divorced woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, she has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Her potential customers are town dwellers. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a retail shop business in the future.

With the Kshs 5,000 she wants to purchase sacks of ground nuts, wheat flour and sweets. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of ground nuts, wheat flour and sweets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy haberdashery items.

loans.name: Anar's Group

texts.en:
Anar, 48, is the leader of this group. Anar’s family is a typical Kyrgyz family with average income. Anar is a seamstress, while her husband is a construction worker. Despite not having a very high income, Anar is happy with her choice of profession, because she enjoys the process of sewing and designing so much that it’s not even considered as a burden by her. 

Anar’s husband is the main breadwinner, constructing buildings and in addition driving a cab. This is a slow time for Anar’s sewing business, which allowed her to get involved in repairing the local high school. The school was built several decades ago, and is currently in a deplorable condition. Anar, along with other residents of the town, have invested some of their savings in repairing the school building. Presently, the construction is coming to an end. Anar plans to purchase building materials for the roof. With this purpose she approached Kiva lenders. She believes it’s noble work and promises to repay the loan on time without any violations. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 37 years old and is married with two children who are 11 months and 3 years old. Vincent makes a living by selling cows. He has been in this business for about three years and the hours of his business are from 6am until 5pm every day except Saturday. He currently employs two people to help him.
Vincent has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more cows for resale. With his profit, Vincent hopes that the number of customers will increase as well as his profits. These profits will be used for further reinvestment and to build a secure future for his family.

loans.use: to purchase more cows for resale.

loans.name: Janysh's Group

texts.en:
Janysh, 46, is the leader of this group. As she lives in a resort town with a constant flow of tourists she, just like many other residents, is involved in entrepreneurship. Janysh leases out pavilions near her house. The pavilions are located in a crowded and advantageous place, where many customers for any business can be attracted. Thanks to inflation and the expansion of the resort, Janysh can raise the prices for lease every season. Her business is 11 years old and currently generates 7,500 soms monthly. Since both of her children are grown and live separately, this income covers all her expenses fairly.
Janysh’s husband is a truck driver, and it was him who pushed her to discovering her new business idea. Way back in the past, he noticed Janysh’s tendency to manage things well. He suggested that she rent a small local cafe and start operating it. Janysh supports his ambitions and therefore applied for a loan from Kiva. The loan will be spent on covering part of the rent expenses.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to rent a cafe.

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en:
Luvuno, a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school, lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, Luvuno has operated a clothes-selling business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She also operates a hairdressing business. Luvuno decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business, and with a loan of Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for sale.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Married to a day laborer, Joice is 35 years old,and she have seven children, none of them is schooling. Joice will use the loan to expand her food -vending business in order to increase her income. and it will be very easy for her for taking care of the children

loans.use: to expand her business.

loans.name: Janylkan's Group

texts.en:
Janylkan, the 41-year-old leader of this group, resides in the town of Balykchi, which is translated from the Kyrgyz language as “Fisher.” Balykchi is a small fishing town situated by Issyk Kul lake, a location that affords many business opportunities to local residents. A high percentage of the 42,000 residents rely on summer tourism to bring in a large number of visitors both from abroad and from within the republic.

With good cooking skills, Janylkan has worked as a cook in a high school cafeteria for many years. One time she learned that a small café was available for rent; seeing her opportunity, she decided to start operating it. Summer months turned out to be even more successful than she expected, so Janylkan soon bought the café. Currently, this restaurant owner also rents a second café where she offers a menu of both national and European meals, earning a total monthly income of 40,000 soms, while the initial capital was 25,000 soms. Janylkan would like to spend her portion of the loan on furnishings and foodstuffs for the café, and in the long run hopes to open a restaurant in the capital as well.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase dishes, foodstuffs and drinks.

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en:
Kwekwe is a married woman with five children; three of her children attend school while two are still too young. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past four years, Kwekwe has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passers-by. She faces the major challenge of the increase in prices of goods at the market when there is food shortage. Kwekwe dreams of expanding and establishing another business in the future.
With the loan of 5,000 Kshs, she wants to purchase sweet potatoes and open a retail shop business. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweet potatoes, and open a retail shop business.

loans.name: La Patience Group

texts.fr: Le groupe LA PATIENCE est formé de trois personnes qui sont issues de la même famille et qui habitent ensemble dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Françoise, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Françoise est âgée de 39 ans et est mariée à un certain Jacob. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés. Françoise vit ensemble avec son mari et participe avec lui aux charges du ménage grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Françoise a très peu fréquenté l'école. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Françoise mène comme activité la vente de maïs, de riz et des condiments de sauce de façon secondaire. Françoise achète ses produits dans un marché du Sud du Bénin et les vend à son domicile. La demande de sa clientèle devient de plus en plus grande et compte tenu de ses moyens limités, Françoise n'arrive plus à bien répondre à leurs exigences. Eu égard à cela et compte tenu de leurs ressources limitées, Françoise et les autres membres du groupe LA PATIENCE sollicitent ensemble un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Group La Patience is composed of three people from the same family who live together in the same district in Benin. The group's representative, named Françoise, is the woman raising her hand in the picture. This is the first time that this group is requesting ALIDé's financial support in order to raise their level of activity.
Françoise is 39 years old and married to a man named Jacob. The couple has six children, who all go to school. Françoise lives with her husband and supports the family with him thanks to the revenues that she derives from her business. Françoise hasn't got much schooling. She has been in the business of selling corn and rice for about ten years; secondarily, she sells condiments for sauces. Françoise purchases her products from a market in southern Benin and sells them from her home.
Demand from her customers is growing, and given her limited means, Françoise is having difficulties meeting their requirements. In view of this and of their limited resources, Françoise and the other members of group La Patience are requesting a loan from ALIDé together.

loans.use: to buy corn and condiments for sauces.

loans.name: Kanyshai's Group

texts.en:
Kanyshai, 49, is the treasurer of this group. Due to a terrible accident that happened to her husband, who later became disabled, Kanyshai became the main breadwinner of the family. She has been sewing national clothing and selling traditional home appliances for 15 years. With the help of her 17-year-old daughter she manages to attract additional income to the family budget by cattle breeding and reselling. At the moment, her monthly income is 3,000 soms, which helps towards the construction of her house. Her initial investment in the business was 10,000 soms. Her requested loan will be invested in the business by purchasing raw materials for sewing.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials.

loans.name: Chinyavu

texts.en:
Chinyavu is a divorced woman with five children, four of whom attend school while the other is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has piped water but no electricity.
Chinyavu operates a grocery business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passers-by. She faces the major challenge of the high cost of purchasing vegetables for her business hence making lower profits. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business to earn more profits in the future.
With her loan of 10,000 KES, she wants to purchase bundles of green vegetables, cabbages and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of green vegetables, cabbages and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 31 years old and is married with two children aged 8 and 10. Jacqueline makes her living by tailoring different styles of clothes for elders and children. She has been in this business for 12 years. She operates her business from 8am until 6pm every day except Saturday, and she currently employs two people to help her.
Jacqueline has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase two sewing machines. By expanding her business and adding more equipment and workers, Jacqueline will hopefully earn more profits. These profits will allow her to create other areas of the same business. In addition, she and her family will be able to get their own home and she will be able to buy a cow to make fertilizer for her field.

loans.use: to purchase two sewing machines for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Muyassarkhan's Group

texts.en:
Muyassarkhan, 39, is the leader of this group. She resides in the small town of Aravan in the south of the republic. For the past 15 years, her daily routine has consisted of feeding and watering the cattle, taking it on high pastures to get sun and fresh air and then back to the shed. Cattle breeding is not Muyassarkhan's only activity; she has also graduated with a degree in medicine and has been working in this sphere for almost two decades. Since the monthly income of medical personnel is only 7,000 soms, Muyassarkhan attempted to find an additional source of income. She invested 5,000 soms of family savings to purchase her very first heads of cattle. She did her best to promote the business and soon, thanks to generated profits, she managed to make repairs to her house and expand her herd. Cattle breeding and resale take much time and energy and brings 4,000 soms monthly. Muyassarkhan has many plans for the future, including providing college education for three of her children and opening a grocery store and a small pharmacy.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Janylbubu's Group

texts.en:
Janylbubu, 64, is a treasurer of this group. 

She has been a shepherd for the past 20 years. However, the burden of raising, milking and reselling cattle was laid on her own shoulders when she was widowed several years ago. 

Fortunately, her two grown sons do their best to help her with this hard labor. The initial capital for the business start-up was 8,000 KGS, which was borrowed from a bank by her brother. A monthly income of 4,600 KGS allows Janylbubu to invest some funds back into the business, as well as save some for personal use. 

At the present time she doesn’t have many head of cattle. She says three head are just enough for yielding milk and getting enough profits. 

The purpose of the loan is to purchase a dairy cow for selling milk products. The entrepreneur and her group are grateful to lenders for financial assistance. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a divorced woman with one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and clothing for the family. 

For the past six months, she has operated a grocery selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge in that vegetables and fruits rot when few customers purchase them. She dreams of expanding her business and of starting a livestock selling business. 

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, green vegetables, cabbages, onions and mangoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of tomatoes, green vegetables, cabbages, onions and mangoes.

loans.name: Mahudjro Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHUDJRO est formé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Eloïse, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Eloïse est âgée de 45 ans et est mariée à un conducteur nommé Thimothé. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous à leurs charges. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants et subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Eloïse a très peu fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de quatre ans que Eloïse exerce comme activité, la vente de bouteilles dans un marché du Bénin ; ce qui lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté aux besoins de sa famille. Eloïse s'approvisionne en bouteilles dans différentes villes du Bénin. Dans le souci de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Eloïse désire renforcer davantage son activité. Pour ce faire, Eloïse sollicite, ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MAHUDJRO, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Mahudjro Group is composed of three people living in the same neighborhood in Benin. The representative of the group is Éloïse, who is raising her hand in the photo. It is the second time that this group applies for financial assistance from the microfinance institution Alidé to raise their activity level. Éloïse is 45 years old and married to Thimothé, a driver. The spouses have five children, all of them being in their care. Some of the children attend school. The parents live with their children and share the various household expenses. Éloïse has had very little formal education.

Éloïse has been selling bottles at a market in Benin for nearly four years, which enables her to provide for her family without major difficulties. Éloïse gets her supply of bottles in various cities in Benin. Eager to better meet the demand of her customers, she wants to give a new boost to her activity. Therefore, Éloïse and her fellow members of Mahudjro Group came to Alidé and applied for their second loan.

loans.use: to buy various bottles.

loans.name: Aslanbek's Group

texts.en:
Aslanbek, 28, is a member of this group. Together with his wife and a son, he resides in a small southern town of Kadamjai, a place with a vast deposit of coal. 

He works in a natural gas processing plant, along with that, he owns some young calves, which he fattens and resells. The achieved results include the purchase of an automobile and a monthly income of 1,500 KGS. 

He hopes to develop the business better, because he plans to continue his education. The purpose of the loan is a payment for education. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
