As they need to increase their working capital, the group members have joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and are on their seventh solidarity loan.

Baya is renowned in Hamdallaye for the sale of her high quality cereals at the Château market in Ségou. She is planning to use her loan to buy three sacks of rice from the Niono fairpeople at Ségou's Grand Market. She resells the rice for cash and on credit from her home and at the Château market to a customer base made up of men and women.

With this loan Baya is hoping to make an average monthly profit of 25,000FCFA, which will be used to reinvest in her business and to provide for small household necessities. Her ambition is through this relationship with Soro Yiriwaso to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is 38 years old, married with two children. He has operated a tailoring business for 14 years and has employed two people. He runs his business in a very competitive environment but is able to retain his customers because of his good customer care. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been trained in business management skills. David hopes to expand his business and open other outlets in the future. He has requested 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy fabric.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est composé de quatre femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans et 4 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché Château de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font le commerce d’articles divers : des habits (pagnes wax et bazins), des fruits (banane et mangue), de l’arachide et du bois de chauffe. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8ème prêt solidaire. 
Oumou, qui est la deuxième femmes debout à droite, une écharpe noire au cou, vend de l’arachide durant toute l’année dans le quartier Hamdallaye et au marché Château de Ségou. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 3 sacs d’arachide en gousse frais en gros avec les producteurs à Seribala. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant  et au marché Château de Ségou à une clientèle mixte.
Oumou espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
Group Danaya is composed of four married women, mainly from polygamous families. They are on average 46 years old with four children each. They all live in the Hamdallaye area in Segou (Mali's fourth administrative region), and they got to know each other through their for-profit activities at the 'Chateau de Segou' market. The group members trade in various items: clothes (wax-style and brocade fabrics), fruits (bananas and mangoes), groundnuts and firewood.
Needing to increase their working capital, the group members decided to partner with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their eight solidarity loan.
Oumou, the second woman from the right in the picture, wearing a black scarf, sells groundnuts year round in the Hamdallaye area and in the 'Chateau de Segou' market. She plans on using her loan to buy three bags of fresh unshelled groundnuts wholesale from Seribala growers. She retails to a mixed-gender clientele from her home, door-to-door and in the 'Chateau de Segou' market, and accepts cash or credit.
With this loan, Oumou hopes to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 CFA, which will be used to reinvest in her activity and to pay for her children's healthcare.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is 47 years of age and married with five children. Two of the children work and the other three are getting their education from a nearby school. Her husband is a farmer by profession. He grows different seasonal crops and earns money for his family. He also sells animals such as sheep and goats to butchers for profits. His sales increase on Eid (Muslims occasion) because people buys animals for slaughtering. She knows the art of clothes sewing. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients for a reasonable income. This income helps her to pay the utility bills and manage other household expenses.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy some goats to sell. This will help him expand his business and increase his profits. He has been operating his business for the past 30 years and Razia hopes that the loan investment will be a profitable experience for him. She is a new loan user of Asasah.

loans.use: To buy goats to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a lady aged 38 years old and her spouse is Edward. She has three children aged 12, eight and five. Betty raises poultry and livestock on her farm, which has been in operation for four years, earning a monthly income of KES.16,500.

Betty has borrowed a loan of KES. 35,000 – this being her third loan after successfully repaying the previous ones.  She wishes to use this amount to add poultry and purchase poultry feed. With the anticipated income she will open a retail shop. Her dream is to own to a large retail shop in the area in future.

loans.use: To purchase poultry feed and add more poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase one dairy cow and dairy feed

loans.name: Alla Kan Soutra. Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf membres du groupe ALLA KAN SOUTRA sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41ans, 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à BATIEMOGOBOUGOU, un des villages de la commune de LOULOUNI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide avec   AMINATA au milieu de la position debout.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et la semence pour entretenir : 2 hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché du village de DALLEN et au marché de LOULOUNI après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 165.500FCFA en fin de  campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The nine members of group Alla Kan Soutra are married women who are on average 41 years old with five children; most of them live in polygamous families in Batiemogobougou, one of the villages of Loulouni Township in Loulouni sub-prefecture, Mali's third administrative region.
They are partnering with micro-finance organization Soro Yiriwaso to manage their agricultural activities during the rainy season. They are on their third loan with the organization. Previous loans well successfully repaid.
Aminata, who is standing in the middle in the picture, cultivates groundnuts. With her loan, she plans on paying for fertilizer and seeds to maintain five acres. After the harvest, the crop is sold in the village and at markets in Dallen and Loulouni, to a clientele comprising men and women.
She expects an average profit of about 165,000 CFA at the end of the agricultural cycle. This profit will help her pay back her loan and support her husband with daily expenses.
She wishes to continue this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso to operate an even larger cultivation space, the better to increase her revenues.

loans.use: to pay for plowing costs and to buy agricultural inputs (such as fertilizers and seeds).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice, cooking fat and maize flour.

loans.name: Enkhbold

texts.en: Mr. Enkhbold is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children, 19, 16 and 14, two of them in secondary school. He has been working as a salesman in a small construction retail and service company since 2010. His wife runs a private business of construction decoration. The family is planning to renovate their house to improve their living conditions, which he thinks will be important to the further education of his children.

loans.use: To renovate his house for better living condition.

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
Pheap is 35 years old and she is a fruit seller.  Her husband is a tractor driver and their income is $13 per day.  They have 2 children ages 13 and 15 years old.  All of the children are studying in school.  

Every month, she has to spend $25 on food, $10 on electricity, and $15 on school fees.  She would like to request a loan of $400 to buy more fruit to sell. She has a lot of costumers because she has been selling for almost 2 year now.  In the future she wants to extend her store to sell more fruits and she wants to repair her house.  For her children, she will send them to study at least finish high school.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Janylkan

texts.en:
Janylkan, 53, is the leader of this group.  Unfortunately she is a widow.  She has raised seven children: six sons and a daughter.  The daughter studies in school, the three older sons are working in Bishkek and the other sons live with Janylkan and help her with housework.  

In 1994 Janylkan started to sell foodstuffs at the market.  With the profits gained she purchased clothing for resale.  At the moment she is engaged in clothing sales.  Her monthly profit is 5,000 soms.  This profit made it possible for her to repair the house.  She applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds to purchase more clothes in order to increase the turnover in her business.  In the future Janylkan wants to see all her children get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar has been practicing mixed farming for the last 4 years in Kitale town, western Kenya.  His farm is currently producing milk and maize which he sells to middlemen.  He earns additional income from his pool table business in the same location.  He is 31 years old and married with no children.

Edgar has made a loan request of 61,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  With the dairy cow he will acquire, he says that his family will be guaranteed enough milk for domestic consumption and sale.  He plans to acquire more dairy cows in the future and also put up a posho mill to help supplement his farming income.  His biggest challenge has been diseases which affect his production.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lubna

texts.en:
Lubna is a 34-year-old married young woman who lives in Jabalia refugee camp, which is located in Gaza Strip. She wants a loan of $1,000 to purchase home furniture since her husband, who is a Palestinian National Authority employee, has a decent salary that doesn't help him buy furniture in cash.  FATEN's loan is repaid on a monthly basis and will enable the family to have better furniture than what they have now, taking into consideration that Lubna lives in a refugee camp that is characterized by poverty. Lubna is in urgent need to get the loan in order to have the furniture, which will improve her daily life.

Lubna is a conservative woman. Therefore, her husband is photographed instead in the furniture shop.

loans.use: to purchase home furniture.

loans.name: Kotognogontala  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA I sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à SOGODOGOLA, un des quartiers de la commune de KAI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI,préfecture de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide  avec NASSARAN 2ème à droite position debout.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et la semence pour entretenir : 1hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de LOULOUNI et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 125.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group KOTOGNOGONTALA I are married women who average 40 years of age and four children living for the most part in polygamous families in SOGODOGOLA, a district in the Commune of  KAI, in the sub-prefecture of LOULOUNI, Prefecture of Kadiolo (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the off-season. The group members are on their fourth loan with the institution. The past loans have been properly repaid. 

The crop grown is: peanuts.  Such is the case with NASSARAN, who is standing second from the right in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and to buy farm inputs and seeds for maintaining one hectare. After the harvest, the produce is sold in villages, at the markets of LOULOUNI and SIKASSO, to a customer base composed of women and men. 

NASSARAN plans on making an average profit of 125,500 francs CFA per planting. The profits will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses. 

She would like to keep up this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to make use of a larger arable plot, so she can derive better gains.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, farm inputs, and seeds

loans.name: Sevada

texts.en: Sevada keeps livestock and cultivates land. He has been engaged in agriculture for the past five years. Sevada needs some financial means to finish cultivating the land. With the loan’s help, Sevada will cultivate the land successfully and develop agriculture. Agricultural development will help Sevada increase his income and support his son in starting a new family. Besides, Sevada wants his daughter to get a high education, so additional income will help him to pay for her education in the future. Sevada lives together with his wife, son and daughter.

loans.use: to finish cultivating his land

loans.name: Prudencienne

texts.en:
Prudencienne is 53 years old and she has five children who are ages 4-24 years old.  Three of her children have completed primary school and stopped going to school, the other one is too young and she is not yet school age while the other one is in primary school.  Her husband is a farmer. 

Prudancienne sells food stuffs and she has done this business for the past 14 years.  This business has enabled her meet the needs of her family.  She needs a loan to buy more food stuffs such as beans in order to make more profits

loans.use: Buying food stuffs for sale.

loans.name: C9231 Twisungane Group

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 49 years old and married with four children between the ages of 4 and 18 years old. She owns a business selling food crops. 

Jacqueline is the leader of this group, which is called " TWISUNGANE" in the local language.  In English it means "BEING TOGETHER". She is the third person on the right side. Jacqueline has been in this business for about one year and her business is open from 7 am until 6 pm every day.

Jacqueline and her team have requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to increase their food crops. Jacqueline and her team will reinvest any profits in their businesses and save for their family's future.

loans.use: To purchase more food crops to sell.

loans.name: Suiumkan

texts.en:
Suiumkan, age 55, is a resident of Tup a small nice village in Isykul region.  Unfortunately Suiumkan is a widow.  She has raised three daughters and a son.  The older son and the first daughter are married and live separately with their families; the other two daughters study at the university. 

Sixteen years ago, Suiumkan, with an initial investment of 1,000 soms started to sell foodstuffs at the market.  At the moment she owns a butcher shop. With money received from the loan Suiumkan wants to purchase seven sheep for breeding and fattening.  In the future, with the profits gained from her business she wishes to build a big house for the children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Kotognogontala  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA I sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 3 5 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à  OUELENI FIEBALA, un des villages de la commune de KAI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide  avec FANTA 2ème à droite position debout.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et la semence pour entretenir : 2hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de LOULOUNI et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 165.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group KOTOGNOGONTALA I are married women who average 35 years of age and four children each. They live for the most part in polygamous families in OUELENI FIEBALA, a village in the Commune of KAI, in the sub-prefecture of LOULOUNI (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the off-season. The group members are on their fourth loan with the institution. The past loans have been properly repaid.

The crop grown is: peanuts.  Such is the case with FANTA, who is standing second from the right in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and to buy farm inputs and seeds for maintaining:  2 hectare. After the harvest, the produce is sold in villages, at the markets of LOULOUNI and SIKASSO, to a customer base composed of women and men.


FANTA plans on making an average profit of 165,500 francs CFA per planting. The profits will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

She would like to keep up this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to make use of a larger arable plot, so she can derive better gains.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, farm inputs, and seeds

loans.name: Jain

texts.en:
Jain is 32 years old, married and has five children; two of them go to school. She sells produce such as tomatoes, pineapples, apples, etc.

Jain is requesting a loan to expand her business. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to make her family’s life smoother and to build a wooden house.

loans.use: to expand her business.

loans.name: Hasmik

texts.en: Hasmik works at the local village hall. Together with her husband, they keep cattle and a few chickens. Hasmik has an orchard, and cultivates land. Hasmik would like to increase the number of livestock and grow potatoes. With the requested loan, she plans to purchase calves and potato seeds. With the loan’s help, Hasmik will increase her income and develop her business further. Hasmik lives together with her husband. Her children left home with their families to find work abroad.

loans.use: to pay for calves and potato seeds

loans.name: Sasun

texts.en: Sasun works at the village hall. Nonetheless, his family’s main income comes from agriculture. Sasun has his own agricultural machinery. He keeps cattle, has an orchard and cultivates land. Sasun would like to increase the number of livestock and develop his business further. With the requested loan, he plans to purchase calves. Increasing the number of livestock will help Sasun to get more income and improve his family’s living conditions. Sasun lives together with his wife and three children.

loans.use: to pay for calves

loans.name: Janyl's Group

texts.en:
Janyl, 34, is married and has two daughters and a son, all of whom study at school. In order to meet the family's needs, her husband has gone to work in Russia. Janyl is the leader of this group.

Ten years ago Janyl started farming. In this way she earns an additional 1,000 KGS to the family budget. With her loan Janyl wants to purchase mineral fertilizers for her farm.

In the future she wants to give all of her children a good education.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers for her farm.

loans.name: Kotognogontala  Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA II sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41ans,  5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à SOGODOGOLA, un des quartiers de la commune de KAI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, préfecture de Kadiolo  3ème région administrative du Mali.

La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide  avec KANIMOGO  2ème à droite position debout.

Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the off-season. The group members are on their fourth loan with the institution. The past loans have been properly repaid.

The crop grown is: peanuts.  Such is the case with KANIMOGO, who is standing second from the right in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and to buy farm inputs and seeds for maintaining 2 hectare. After the harvest, the produce is sold in villages, at the markets of LOULOUNI and SIKASSO, to a customer base composed of women and men.

KANIMOGO plans on making an average profit of 165,500 francs CFA per planting. The profits will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

She would like to keep up this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to make use of a larger arable plot, so she can derive better gains.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, farm inputs, and seeds

Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage.

La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide  avec KANIBA 1ère à gauche position debout.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et la semence pour entretenir : 2hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de LOULOUNI et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 165.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The ten members of the KOTOGNOGONTALA II group are married women with an average age of 34 years, an average of four children, and most living in polygamous families in Ouéléni Fièbala, a village in the commune of Kaï in the sub-prefecture of Loulouni, in the 3rd administrative region of Mali.  They work with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season.  They are on their fourth loan with the organization, their former loans having been paid back.  

Kaniba, standing at left, cultivates peanuts.  With her loan she plans to pay labor costs and buy fertilizer and seeds to maintain two hectares.  The crop is sold in the village at the Loulouni market and in the Sikasso market after harvest to a customer base of both men and women.  She expects to make an average profit of 165,500 FCFA per growing season.  This profit will allow her to pay her loan and also to help her husband with daily expenses.  She wishes to maintain this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to cultivate a larger area and earn more profit.

loans.use: to pay agricultural labor costs and buy fertilizer and seed.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is engaged in retail. She imports women’s shoes and bags from abroad and sells from a rented booth at the city market. Trading is the family’s main source of income. Mariam has to renew the stock regularly, and that requires additional financial investment. With the loan’s help Mariam will be able to increase the trade, meet clients’ demands and sustain her family.

loans.use: to pay for shoes.

loans.name: Aikan's Group

texts.en:
Aikan is the leader of this group. She is 27 and married to a construction worker. The family lives in Nookat, a small village in the south of Kyrgyzstan.

Aikan works as a tax inspector, and her monthly salary is 3,100 KES. In order to earn additional money to meet the household’s daily needs, the family breeds cattle.

Aikan applied for this loan because she needs additional funds to buy more cattle for breeding. She wants to save money to start building a new house.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Babgen

texts.en: Babken is engaged in pig-breeding. He would like to increase the number of pigs and found a large farm. With the loan’s help Babken will develop his business and increase his income. Additional income will help Babken insure a sustainable future for his family of five. Babken lives together with his wife, son and two daughters.

loans.use: to pay for pigs.

loans.name: Kotognogontala Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA III sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  39 ans,  3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à SOGODOGOLA, un des quartiers de la commune de KAI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, préfecture de Kadilo 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide  avec  BINTOU 2ème à droite position assise.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et la semence pour entretenir : 2 hectares.

Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, farm inputs, and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a water tank and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Tumarkan's Group

texts.en:
Tumarkan is 47 and married to an electrician. Together with her husband she has raised three sons and a daughter. The youngest son studies at school while the other children are married and live separately with their families. Tumarkan is the leader of this group.

Tumarkan works as a nurse, and her monthly salary is 5,000 KGS. In order to earn additional money to meet the family’s needs, Tumarkan breeds cattle. With the money received from her loan she wants to purchase more cattle for breeding.

In the future with the profits gained from her business, she wants to purchase a vehicle for the family. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Kotognogontala Iii Group
